President George W.
Bush over the past eight years.
Over the next few weeks, we'll look at both the successes and failures of the Bush administration.
We begin today with Daron Shaw.
He teaches political science at the University of Texas at Austin.
He also served on both Bush/Cheney campaigns.
Shaw says to understand his legacy, you need to look all the way back to 2001, when George W.
Bush first took office.
The president was very focused on tax cuts, obviously, and on reforming the education system.

And there's a bit of irony there because he was a Republican president who came in with very, very significant aspirations to increase the level of federal control or involvement in the setting of standards in the educational system.
Looking over these past eight years, what kind of legacy do you think he actually does leave behind?
Boy, that's the tough question.
In political science, we're a little different from historians.

What we tend to do is to focus on, when we evaluate presidents, the extent to which they articulate an agenda, get that agenda passed in the legislation, follow through on those public policy commitments and in statutes and laws that are enacted.

And so, you know, for instance, there may be people who have public policy differences with the president like Franklin Roosevelt or, more recently, Ronald Reagan, but amongst political scientists that regard them as very, very effective, good presidents because they meet these sort of objective criteria.
You may not like what Roosevelt did, but you know, nobody argues that he didn't articulate a vision, that he didn't get that vision passed into law and then follow through on it.
It's very hard to sort of think of Bush in those terms.
I mean, even using those objective criteria, there's a lot of subjective room for appraisal.
You know, early on he had the tax cuts; he had No Child Left Behind, controversial, but got it passed; prescription drug plan; reorganization of Homeland Security.
But then, as you move to the second administration, the two major legislative initiatives - social security reform, which was dead on arrival, and immigration reform - went nowhere.
So, it's very mixed even in those terms.

Setting aside issues like the Iraq war, the war in Afghanistan, questions of expansion of executive authority, I think those things are going to take years, maybe decades, to sort of settle; it's going to take a lot of time.
There are people now who can't stand those things and are ready to throw, you know, dirt on the grave of the Bush administration, both Bush I and Bush II.
I mean, I'm not sure.
I'm just not as convinced that the record is this open and shut as some people seem to think it is at this point.
In the final months of his administration, of course, one of the biggest stories has been the economy, which right now is looking incredibly grim here in the U.S.
To what extent do you think that President Bush should be held accountable for that?
Well, presidents are held accountable whether it's fair or not.
I think - my sense is that in some ways, presidents are overrated with respect to their ability to impact the economy.
But boy, when the economy went south, he's just going to get it.
Now, is that fair?
In many ways, I think it probably is.

I mean, there's - as a free-market guy and someone who wasn't terribly interested in regulation, a lot of the absence of regulatory policies over some of these Wall Street firms is, you know - it's pretty easy to say, well, look, he did nothing; this was the fundamental problem, the lack of oversight, lack of regulation, you know; ergo, Bush was, if not, you know, culpable, certainly, you know, it happened on his watch.
He didn't do anything to stop it.
That doesn't strike me as being terribly unfair.

You could argue, I think, and as someone who was involved in the Bush campaign '00 and '04, that he got pretty unlucky in a lot of ways, but yeah, ultimately, he's going to bare that responsibility And that's why I think, you know, President Bush is never going to rise to the level of the great or even near great presidents, even if, you know, Afghanistan or Iraq are flourishing democracies in 50 years.
I think that economic legacy is just going to cripple his ability to sort of resurrect his legacy.
Supporters of the president, and the president himself, have pointed out to the fact that since September 11th, 2001, there have been no terrorist attacks on U.S.
soil.
Is that something that can be rightly used as indication of his strengths?
I mean, for my money, I think it's as fair as some of the other things are unfair.
In other words, one of the things you do with presidents is you play a what-if game.

And historians, of course, have written books on this, and if you hold the president accountable for the economy, I think it's reasonable to take, you know, what you have right now - which is the absence of any attacks in the U.S.
homeland over this period of time - and give him credit for that.
Is it possible that would have happened without Bush or that a better policy would have achieved the same effect?
Maybe, but we don't know.

My pleasure being here, Ed.

And I guess I had confidence in the president.
I think that some of the things that happened were absolutely his fault.
I don't think he was served well by a lot of people in his administration.
In fact, I would make the argument that one of the real problems was a misguided sense of loyalty.
There were certain people who, in retrospect, were clearly not loyal to the president, whom he rewarded with service opportunities beyond the time they should have gone.
Politically, it was kind of stunning how things deteriorated, I think.
In terms of substantive policy, I understood some of the problems at the times with the policy.
I supported them.
Some of them have not worked out, and you bear culpability for that, and you know, they make for a lot of second-guessing.
But I think at a personal level this is an honorable man; this is a man who did the best he could.
And I think, you know, in a lot of ways, it's a more - much more complex presidency than people, I think, appreciate right now.

When George W.
Bush leaves the White House, he and his wife Laura will return to Dallas.

For more on their future, we're joined now by Colleen McCain-Nelson of the Dallas Morning News.
She joins us from Dallas, and Colleen, there have been rumors that the president wanted to retire to the ranch in Crawford, but it was Mrs. Bush who was very insistent about Dallas.
What have you heard about their decision?

The president has said that he's no longer the decider-in-chief and that he had the decision to have the ranch kind of be their getaway while he was in the White House, but Laura has long wanted to come back to Dallas.
She went to Southern Methodist University, where the library will be, and has been eager to return to the neighborhood where they lived before heading to the governor's mansion.
They're expected to move into a four-bedroom house.
That seems rather modest after living at 1600 Pennsylvania Ave.
It's definitely downsizing for them.
I've actually seen the house and it doesn't stand out from other houses in the neighborhood.
In fact, compared to some of the mansions in the neighborhood where they'll be living, it is pretty low key and fairly modest.
It's a ranch house, it was built in 1959, and so, driving by, it's not going to wow you, and you're not going to think, well, a former commander-in-chief must live there.
How are the people of Dallas feeling about the Bushes moving back into the neighborhood?
Well, it's a mixed reaction.
You don't see either rioting in the streets and - nor a hero's parade, welcoming him back.
There's kind of some in between, where, I would say, the neighborhood he's returning to is fairly friendly confines.
This is the same neighborhood where they lived previously, so they have some old friends in the neighborhood, and it is a Republican neighborhood, kind of old money.

And so, that will be comfortable for them, but there certainly are folks in Dallas who are not excited about the president living here, whether they completely disagree with his politics, or the other concerns that I have heard from folks are traffic and terrorists, and just wondering whether having a former president here could tie up traffic and also make Dallas a target.
And we've also seen protests both at SMU and within the Methodist Church about bringing the library here.
So, it's an interesting mix of reactions, but as you drive around the neighborhood where they'll be living, you're already seeing some yard signs pop up that say, welcome home, W.
